column4: Hi.  I'm wondering if I have two ubuntu computers on my LAN, is there an easy way to use one as basically nothing more than a display for the other?  Meaning, can I somehow login to a desktop session on the "remote" machine (still on my LAN) using the other machine?
simple way.. ssh -Y otherbox, and run your apps.
a little harder way. enable/use the XDMCP feature of X.
if you want the whole desktop. kde/gnome has a vnc desktop sharing feature (but it can be a bit slow)

Right, I know about ssh and X forwarding, but that's not quite what I'm after.  I'm looking to make it basically so that one you're logged in you're working on the remote machine completely with no sign that it's not the local machine.
I see.  Thanks.
you just described 'xdmcp' :)
in the sessions menus for kdm/gnome theres a  Search for hosts, or query hosts, type feature that can be enabled.
however that can get a big laggy if you start doing copying big files over the network.
the 'vncserver' method would let you have a presistant desktop on eht remove machine

Ok, cool.  I thought XDMCP might be what I was looking for, but I wasn't sure.  Most of the descriptions of it I've seen talk about the technical details rather than giving a concise description of what it does.
using xdmcp and 'xming' in my windows machiens to get a X desktop on them. :)

I don't understand the comment about copying large files.  I was thinking that all operations (say moving files) would be performed on the remote machine.  Or are you just talking about display information?
if a lot of network traffic happens it can lag your display.
the normal use for xdmcp is to let a few dozen+ thin clients have a  'server' they all are using.,
I see.  Well in my case it would just be 1 computer, so that won't be an issue.
Thanks for you help.  I'm going to give it a try.
i just got it set with a 2 pc setup. :) but wheni go copying some iso files from the basement to up here (for me to burn) it can lag my display a little.
